Almost impossible to survive, incredibly unforgiving and for the most part unplayable. I speak from 10 hours of experience so maybe my opinion isn't particularly valid but I really don't like getting surrounded by zeds and torn apart within seconds. On the plus side it has a good variety of weaponry, a selection of interesting maps such as: Biotics Lab, west London, Filths Cross and Suburbia but overall, I never seem to survive longer than 3-4 waves which isn't fun. (Edit: That's not to say i'm dissatisfied enough to stop playing.)

I like this game. It's like someone looked at cod: zombies, and thought:
"Needs to be more terrifying, like exam week! And where's the over-exagerrated, slo-mo gore?"
Oh yeah, and british people.

Now here's the longer part of the review.
Gameplay 8/10
Reason: While it's fun in bursts, it can get boring without friends. Add in new maps, mods, FRIENDS, and challenges, and you get more fun, but this does take effort and deviation away from the actual game, hence the 8/10 instead of 10/10.
Graphics 6/10
Reason: They're good, solid graphics for a game like this one, especially considered it's age, and old computers won't have a problem turning it to high. While this is a good thing in my case, this also means it's not the best in this category. So they're not great. They're not bad. They're just graphics.
Controls 10/10
Reason: I have no trouble what-so-ever with this game's controls, past the lack of controller support (which is to be expected from an older game)
Glitches: 9/10
In all of my hours of this game, I have only met 1, which didn't let me choose a class, but re-launching the game fixed that.

My buddy and I spent hours trying to connect on a game between this and Killing Floor 2. Was a complete waste of money. Anyone know why they made multiplayer so unaproachable or, more so, how to make it work?

Here is my review for the title "Killing Floor", a retail version of the original Unreal Tournament 2004 mod that was released in 2005. Initially, I had high hopes for this game. It had much better improvements than the original mod (though, there were some features that stood out to me and a few others from the mod), like a wider range of more deadlier weapons, more Zeds, and a lot more maps. The mod only had you start out with a pistol, a knife, and dropped you in Horzine's offices. In this 2009 release, there are at least 44 new weapons, as of 2018, including a multitude of DLC releases involving new weapons, characters, and more. It's a really brittle game, with it being simply simple for a studio (Tripwire) that started out as a mod team but ended up releasing an actual decently fun and gory game. I recommend it in it's fully British glory, you'll probably have fun swearing at the Zed's more than dealing with the grinding system, which is one of my complaints with it, as listed below:

Pros-
[list]
[*] Unique assortment of weapons, ranging from a fire axe to the .44 Magnum revolver to assault rifles and explosive weaponry like the M32 Grenade Launcher.
[*] Awesome soundtrack, though, it varies less than Killing Floor 2's. It's mostly grungy, lower aesthetic electronic and rock, which adds to the atmosphere.
[*] Classic Zeds, no funny business here (I'm talking to you, E.D.A.Rs).
[*] Atmosphere adds to the horror, more darker than KF2, which makes the game more horror-y.
[*] Voice lines from the voice actors (3, as I know of?) are pretty top notch and add a sense of British wit and humor while you're fighting off flesh eating clones.
[*] Since it's an old game that runs on Unreal Engine 2.5, it'll work well with your potato toaster-tronic 3000 with a crappy video CPU.
[*] Workshop support! You can download maps, weapon reskins, or whatever to help add some flair to keep the game as spicy as you want.
[/list]

Cons-
[list]
[*] The game has a terrible levelling up system that takes ages upon ages to level up (in my case). If you're not playing it constant, or you're just on a shoddy lower difficulty, then don't expect to reach Level 6 in an instant. More so, KF2's levelling up system is a much better improvement and takes out the element of grinding, plus, you can Prestige it to restart your rank, encouraging replay value.
[*] No new content is being added, since KF2 is now being breast fed by Tripwire, which is both a good and bad thing, but for this, it's a bad thing*.
[*] Latency issues are commonplace in servers that you may not expect to play on. KF2 improves on this with a newer update (as of August 12, 2018) that'll release in October.
[*] Same voicelines, no new innovation. At least they added some female voicelines that're different.
[*] The only boss is the Patriarch. KF2 has at least 4 bosses, including the Patriarch himself. 
[*] The game is pretty old, so you might or might not get bored of it in a while. Up to you.
[*] DLC's prices are bollocks. Costs from 5 to 8 dollars for very simple stuff, like 4 characters that probably no one on the planet will or ever play as.
[/list]

So there, that's my final review of this masterpiece of full gory killing. If you get this game, then it's worth it if you play it from time to time. The fanbase is still active, and the game is still being supported by modders and the community, which is absolutely wonderful. And hey, maybe I'll see you on the Killing Floor myself sometime.

tl;dr: Game is good, suffers from lack of innovation, but makes up for it with it's simplistic killing and enjoyable teamwork play.

*As a note, the game not being updated is good and bad since Tripwire won't affect anything, which is good if you don't want the game to be ruined, but no content means there's less to do than KF2.

Killing Floor es un survival horror que hace honor a su nombre. La modalidad de juego general consiste en un mapa, normalmente no muy grande, que se infesta de oleadas de zombis y, por supuesto, el objetivo es sobrevivir. Para ello tendr√°s que elegir una clase (privilegios), que se especializa en ciertos tipos de armas, decidir estrategias de supervivencia y coordinarte con tu equipo. Entre una oleada y otra hay un breve descanso para comprar armas, para explorar el mapa y para que resuciten los compa√±eros que han muerto, eso si, sin armas m√°s que las b√°sicas.

Aspectos positivos del juego: 

- Diferentes clases con armas variadas le dan dinamismo al juego
- Dificultad apropiada para un survival horror
- Variedad de mapas
- Enf√°sis en la cooperaci√≥n

Aspectos negativos:

- No hay una gran cantidad de jugadores activamente. No obstante, no resultar√° un problema para jugar, pues siempre hay los necesarios.
- Subir de nivel a una clase a veces se torna un poco aburrido.

Por √∫ltimo, el juego posee tambi√©n la modalidad de jugar por objetivos (y no por oleadas) otorgando de m√°s variedad al juego, incluso hay servidores creados por la comunidad cuya din√°mica es totalmente distinta.

Totalmente recomendado para jugar con amigos. Aprovechad en rebajas.

Killing Floor is an relatively perfect game of it's era and still holds up in even 2020. The guns feel just right and powerful in your hands, almost making you feel the devastation of each impact. Nailing head shots let's off explosions of blood and gore in absolute zombie slaying satisfaction. The enemies are nicely modeled and look utterly horrifying and may be too much to bare for younger audiences-- which is just my style of game! 

There's an large array of guns and maps, enough to make the price tag worth it even for offline solo play through. The game has very low system requirements and should be able to run on most computers.

KF also has Steam Workshop enabled which will give your game another 30 to 100 hours worth of game play, depending on your tastes as the game does get repetitive (I can vouch for that).

Overall, I highly recommend Killing Floor for almost anyone into wave based survival games or just love blowing stuff up!

It's been about 8 years since I first & last played this game. All 56 of my current hours are from Solo Play, never tried multiplayer. Even still, it was a pretty fun game, though a bit repetitive. I really like the Gun play, they're all fairly realistic. My favorite was the Winchester Rifle. The Zed-time feature was done very well, getting a headshot has never been more satisfying in any other game that I've played.

I think I only stopped playing because there was an issue with the perk system and my points were reset after all that playtime... To be honest, I didn't think the game would come anywhere near as far as it has. Over the years, I've been watching all these DLCs and stuff come out for this game, which was initially "just another Zombie FPS Survival game", and I think that's pretty cool. From small beginnings and all that jazz.... I just don't like having to constantly pay for new content a la DLC for a game I've already bought.

Anyway, the point is, this game's been out for a long ass time and it still seems to be going strong... Time to put the DLCs and KF2 on the Wishlist and wait for them to go on sale. I'm ready for some more Zed-time.
